codes.label: Trust/confidence in parliament
codes.evidence: Low levels of political trust are associated with a preference for a protest party. As a measure for political trust, we use respondents' indicated level of trust in the following institutions; political parties, the regional government, the regional parliament, the federal government, the federal parliament and politicians.

codes.label: Unclear
codes.evidence: The authors operationalize political trust through six survey items (trust in political parties, regional government, regional parliament, federal government, federal parliament, politicians) on a 0-10 scale but do not provide an explicit conceptual definition of what political trust means theoretically.

codes.label: Comparative (two or more cases)
codes.evidence: We examine voting in the two party systems separately. For the Flemish region... For the French language parties...

codes.label: Case-study (single case)
codes.evidence: In this paper, we investigate the dynamic relation between political trust and voting behaviour by means of a panel design. This allows studying how the trust level of protest voters evolves following their vote decision. We make use of the data from the Belgian Election Panel (2009-2014)
We rely on data from the Belgian Election Panel (2009-2014), in which a representative sample of voters has been surveyed in the context of both the 2009 and the 2014 Belgian elections.

codes.label: Belgium
codes.evidence: We investigate this relation in Belgium, as this country offers an ideal setting, both for the study of political trust as for the study on protest voting.

codes.label: Surveys
codes.evidence: The 2009 part of the panel survey consisted of three survey waves... 1,698 respondents took part in this post-electoral survey wave and were interviewed by phone... these respondents were contacted again to participate in the 2014 part of the panel study. A total of 792 respondents... sent back a paper questionnaire

codes.label: Primary
codes.evidence: We rely on data from the Belgian Election Panel (2009-2014), a representative survey of voters in the two main regions of Belgium (Flanders and Wallonia), based on a sample from the National Register of the citizens of Belgium.

codes.label: Quantitative (descriptive, bivariate, statistical aggregation)
codes.evidence: The mean values for political trust in Table 1 additionally point out a decline in political trust between 2009 and 2014. We first descriptively assess changes in levels of political trust between 2009 and 2014 for the electorates of different parties.

codes.label: Quantitative (statistical modelling, regression analysis)
codes.evidence: we present the results of a series of multinomial logistic regression models... We perform a multivariate analysis explaining the impact of the vote choice in 2009 on levels of political trust in 2014, while controlling for the 2009 level of political trust. For doing so, we run an OLS regression

codes.label: Summary of main findings
codes.evidence: Our findings hint at a 'spiral of distrust'. Low levels of trust as well as decreasing levels of political trust increase the probability of voting for a protest party. Having chosen such a party subsequently acts to decrease one's level of trust in politics even further. The result is a spiral of distrust, where distrust and protest voting enforce each other.

codes.label: Summary of main findings
codes.evidence: Key findings include: (1) public engagement requires inclusivity, diversity, empowerment, flexibility, meaningfulness, and transparency; (2) deliberative approaches improve policy outcomes and legitimacy; (3) New Zealand's engagement strategy improved parliament reputation (53.9 to 61.2 points) and voting commitment (18% to 32%); (4) evaluation frameworks must assess legislative impact, public impact, and hidden impact; (5) Australian parliaments must reach beyond 'usual suspects' to engage marginalized communities including First Nations peoples
